lesson.name: Project 8 Teacher Guide: Modeling Rocket Flight

page.title: Project 8 Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this culminating project, students use their knowledge of quadratic equations in different forms to solve problems.

In the first activity, students are given a graph of a quadratic function and are asked to write the function in factored form. Students will determine how many solutions a function has based on an understanding of its factored form. They will also be able to explain the characteristics of the graph of a quadratic function with no solution.

In the second activity, students work in pairs to fluently rewrite quadratic expressions in factored and standard form using the strategies learned in the unit.

In the third activity, students find the specific equation in standard form of a quadratic function that has certain zeros and passes through a particular point, given a real-world situation. They will use the equation to make a prediction about the situation, given the context of the problem.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Explain why quadratic equations can have no solutions and explain why there are none.
  • Recognize that the number of solutions to a quadratic equation can be revealed when the equation is written as an expression in factored form equal to zero.
  • Write an equivalent expression in factored form given a quadratic expression of the form \(ax^2+ bx + c\), where \(a\) is not 1.
  • Use the intercept form of a quadratic function, \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\), to define a specific function given its zeros and a point.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Explain why quadratic equations can have no solutions and explain why there are none.
  • Recognize quadratic equations that have zero, one, or two solutions when they are written in factored form.
  • Write equivalent expressions in factored form when given quadratic expressions of the form \(ax^2+ bx + c\) and \(a\) is not 1.
  • Use the intercept form of a quadratic function to define a specific function given its zeros and a point.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

  • A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Required Materials

  • Pencil and paper
  • Project 8 Handout

Required Preparation

  • Print one set of tables, found in the Project 8 Handout, for each pair of students in class.

Project Activities

  • Activity P.1: Relating the Graphs of Quadratic Equations to Their Factored Form by Their Zeros
  • Activity P.2: Converting Between Factored Form and Standard Form
  • Activity P.3: Modeling Rocket Flight Using a Quadratic Equation

page.title: Activity P.1: Relating the Graphs of Quadratic Equations to Their Factored Form by Their Zeros
page.contents:
Activity: Relating the Graphs of Quadratic Equations to Their Factored Form by Their Zeros (5 minutes)

This warm up activates students' knowledge of the factored form of a quadratic equation. Students will remember that the factored form of an equation can be derived from its solutions, or zeros, as found in a graph. 

Students will refresh their understanding that a quadratic equation with a single solution is a double root. This can be represented by a parabola that intersects with the \(x\)-axis at one point, its vertex.

Students will also remember that when the graph of a quadratic equation does not intersect with the \(x\)-axis, the equation has no solution.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of two. Give students quiet think time to answer each question (it is not necessary that students formally record their responses). Then, ask them to share their responses with their partner before moving on to the next question. Follow up with a brief whole-class discussion.

Student-Facing Statement

In this unit, you learned about the relationship between the factored form of a quadratic equation, its zeros, and its graph. 

  1. What is the factored form of the quadratic equation represented by the graph? Explain how you found your answer.

 

  1. How many times does the graph of the equation \((x-5)(x-5)=0\) intersect with the \(x\)-axis? Explain your reasoning.

  2. The equation \(x^2-8x+20=0\) is shown in the graph. How many solutions does the equation have? Explain your reasoning.

 

Student Response

  1. The zeros of the quadratic function shown in the graph are -4 and 6. This means the factors of the function are \((x-6)\) and \((x+4)\). The factored form of this function is represented by the equation \((x-6)(x+4)=0\).

  2. The graph of the equation intersects one time with the \(x\)-axis. The solution or zero of the equation \((x-5)(x-5)=0\) is \(x = 5\). It is a double root. This means when graphed, the vertex of the parabola intersects with the \(x\)-axis only at \((5, 0)\).

  3. The equation has no solution. Since the graph of the equation does not intersect with the \(x\)-axis, it does not have a solution.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students:

  • "How do the zeros of a quadratic equation, as found by its graph, relate to its factored form?" (The zeros, or \(x\)-intercepts, of a graph represent the solutions to the quadratic equation. These solutions are found by solving each individual factor in the equation's factored form.)
  • "How does the number of unique solutions to a quadratic equation relate to the number of \(x\)-intercepts of its graph?" (They are equal.)

page.title: Activity P.2: Converting Between Factored Form and Standard Form
page.contents:
Activity: Converting Between Factored Form and Standard Form (20 minutes)

In this activity, students will reinforce skills developed in the unit by converting between the factored form and standard form of quadratic expressions.

Remind students that they can use FOIL to convert from factored form to standard form. In order to convert from standard form to factored form, students must rely on the factoring skills developed during the unit.

Launch

Arrange students into groups of two. Read the instruction in the activity as a class. Provide the "Student A" table of expressions to one student in a pair and the "Student B" table of expressions to the other. 

As students convert their expressions and compare their answers with their partners, observe for any pairs that might need guidance.

Student A

Round 1

\((2a+5)(a+4)\)

Round 2

\(16a^2-25\)

Round 3

\((3a-1)(a-10)\)

Round 4

\(5a^2+33a-14\)

Round 5

\((4a-5)(4a-5)\)

Round 6

\((2a+7)(9a+4)\)

Student B

Round 1

\(2a^2+13a+20\)

Round 2

\((4a-5)(4a+5)\)

Round 3

\(3a^2-31a+10\)

Round 4

\((a+7)(5a-2)\)

Round 5

\(16a^2-40a+25\)

Round 6

\(18a^2+71a+28\)

Support for English Language Learners

Use the following image to help students visualize that in this activity, we will be converting between the factored form and standard form of quadratic expressions and vice versa.



Student-Facing Statement

You have learned strategies for writing a quadratic expression in its factored form and standard form. In each round of this activity, you and your partner will be given equivalent quadratic expressions in different forms. 

The goal of each round is to write the quadratic expression as it has been given to your partner. If your expression is in factored form, write it in standard form. If your expression is in standard form, write it in factored form. At the end of each round, compare the expressions with your partner without revealing the expressions for future rounds.

If, in any round, you need help, you may ask your partner to explain the next step without revealing the solution.

Proceed from rounds 1 to 6 while discussing your thinking if there is any disagreement.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students:

  • "How did you convert from factored form to standard form?" (I used FOIL to multiply each term in each binomial by each other term. Then I simplified like terms to find the standard form of the expression.)
  • "How did you convert from standard form to factored form?"
    • Possible answers include:
      • I used trial and error to find the coefficients of the binomials in factored form.
      • I recognized the difference of squares in one of the expressions in standard form.
      • I worked backward from FOIL to reason the coefficients of each binomial in factored form.
      • I found all the factors of the constant term of the expression in the standard form. I found all of the factors of the leading quadratic coefficient of the expression in the standard form. I found the combination of these factors that correctly added to equal the coefficient of the linear term of the expression in standard form.

page.title: Activity P.3: Modeling Rocket Flight Using a Quadratic Equation
page.contents:
Activity: Modeling Rocket Flight Using a Quadratic Equation (15 minutes)

In lesson 8.11, students learned how to find the specific equation in standard form of a quadratic function that has certain zeros and passes through a particular point. In this activity, students will put those skills to use to find a specific equation that models the path of a rocket given the parameters of the problem. They will then use this equation to make a prediction about its flight.

Launch

Arrange students into groups of two. Allow students time to discuss the problem as a pair. Pause for a whole-class discussion after the first question. Then allow students to continue on to the second question.

Support for Students with Disabilities

Provide students with a list of information that we know and information that we need in order to help visualize how to solve the problem.

  • Things we know:
    • The rocket launches after 1 second and lands after 6 seconds. (The zeros of the function are 1 and 6.)
    • After 5 seconds, the rocket has a height of 8 meters. (The function passes through the point \((5, 8)\).)
  • Things we need to know:
    • The value of \(a\) in the intercept form of the function, \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\).
    • The standard form of the function.

Student-Facing Statement

Alejandra lights the fuse on a small toy rocket. The fuse burns down and, after 1 second, the rocket launches into the air. The rocket lands back on the ground after 6 seconds.

After 5 seconds from when Alejandra lit the fuse, the height of the rocket was 8 meters.

  1. What is the quadratic equation in standard form that models the flight of the rocket? (Hint: Think of the problem as a quadratic function in which you know the zeros and a point through which the function passes.)
  2. Use the equation you found in the previous question to find the height of the rocket, in meters, 3 seconds after Alejandra lit the fuse.

Student Response

  1. Since the rocket left the ground at 1 second after Alejandra lit the fuse and it landed again 6 seconds after, we know the zeros of the quadratic equation are 1 and 6.

This means the factored form of the quadratic equation modeling the flight of the rocket is \(f(x) =(x-1)(x-6)\).

We also know that at 5 seconds after Alejandra lit the fuse, the rocket was at a height of 8 meters. This means the quadratic equation we are looking for passes through the point \((5, 8)\).

We can use the intercept form of the quadratic equation to find the standard form we want.

We know the intercept form of a quadratic equation is \(f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q)\).

To find the value of \(a\), we can substitute the zeros for \(p\) and \(q\). We can also substitute 5 for \(x\) and 8 for \(f(x)\).

\(\begin{array}{rcl}f(x)\;&=&\;a(x\;-\;p)(x\;-\;q)\\f(x)\;&=&\;a(x\;-\;1)(x\;-\;6)\\8&=&\;a((5)\;-\;1)((5)\;-\;6)\\8&=&\;a(4)(-1)\\8&=&\;-4a\\-2&=&\;a\\&&\end{array}\)

We can now substitute -2 back into the equation in intercept form for \(a\). Again, we can substitute the zeros for \(p\) and \(q\).

\(\begin{array}{rcl}f(x)\;&=&\;a(x\;-\;p)(x\;-\;q)\\f(x)\;&=&\;-2(x\;-\;1)(x\;-\;6)\\f(x)\;&=&\;-2(x^2-7x+6)\\f(x)\;&=&\;-2x^2+14x-12\\&&\end{array}\)

So, the quadratic equation in standard form that models the flight of the rocket is \(f(x) = -2x^2+14x-12\).

  1. To find the height of the rocket 3 seconds after Alejandra lit the fuse, we substitute 3 for \(x\) in the equation we just found.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}f(x)&=&-2x^2+14x-12\\f(x)&=&-2(3)^2+14(3)-12\\f(x)\;&=&\;-2(9)+42-12\\f(x)\;&=&\;-18+42-12\\f(x)\;&=&\;12\end{array}\)

The rocket was at 12 meters exactly 3 seconds after Alejandra lit the fuse.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students might look at the zeros of the function and think that the equation they are looking for is the standard form equivalent of the function \(f(x) =(x-1)(x-6)\), or \(f(x) =x^2-7x+6\). This function does not pass through the point \((5, 8)\). Remind students that though this function is related to the function we want, since it shares the same zeros, it is not the specific function we want. If students graph the function \(f(x) =x^2-7x+6\), they will see it does not model a possible flight path of a rocket.

Activity Synthesis

Show students the graph of the function from the activity using Desmos here.

Ask students:

  • Summarize, in your own words, how you found the equation in standard form that models the flight of the rocket. (Sample answer: I analyzed the problem to find the zeros of the function. I used the zeros of the function and the point through which the function passes to find the value of \(a\) in the intercept form of the function. I substituted the value of \(a\) and the zeros into the intercept form of the function. I simplified the equation to find the standard form of the function.)
  • Is it possible to model the flight of a rocket that has the same zeros but reaches a different maximum height as the rocket in this activity? Explain. (Yes. The equation modeling the flight of that rocket would be related to the equation we found, since they would have the same zeros. It would, however, have different coefficients in standard form, since it passes through a different point.)
